image.altText: Putin poses against a tree, dressed in outdoorsy clothing

items.synopsis: Russia's president may have placed himself at the pinnacle of a so-called "power vertical", but some believe one "humiliating" weekend could be the beginning of the end for his regime.

title.children: 'Absolute dismay and confusion': A picture is emerging of Putin in crisis. It could threaten his rule

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: In a speech to be delivered at the Garma Festival, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will promise to hold the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum this year, rejecting calls to delay or cancel the referendum.

title.children: 'We will not deny the urgency of this moment': Albanese to promise to hold Voice referendum in 2023

image.altText: auction sign out from of two storey home

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank's mission to bring inflation down to its target range of between 2 and 3 per cent appears to be on track, but how confident of this can we be? Movements in the Australian dollar give us some clues, writes David Taylor.

title.children: What the fall in the Australian dollar tells us about the future of interest rate rises

image.altText: A woman taking a selfie

items.synopsis: A 34-year-old woman on bail for her alleged role in a 2021 murder has asked the Supreme Court to send her back to prison because of the "daily battle just trying to find suitable accommodation".

title.children: Woman on bail unable to find housing asks court to send her back to jail, judge agrees

items.synopsis: There's a common cycle for many children in this town: Crime, watch house, detention. Background Briefing investigates why.

title.children: Marty woke to find three intruders in his bedroom. His story is one of hundreds from his hometown

image.altText: Aerial photo of Groote Eylandt coast line.

items.synopsis: Police say spears, crossbows and machetes have been used in the violence which involved up to 150 people on the island in the Gulf of Carpentaria.

title.children: Trio hospitalised after violent outbreak on tropical NT island

image.altText: White man with hat walks in the middle of a group of Indigenous people in traditional dress carrying red flags

items.synopsis: When Anthony Albanese confirmed at the Garma Festival 12 months ago that his new government would go ahead with a referendum on Indigenous recognition and an Indigenous Voice, the Arnhem Land air seemed full of optimism. Since then, things have not been going well, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The Voice was supposed to unify Australians. Where has the optimism gone?

items.synopsis: There are calls for Queensland to follow Victoria's lead, which reduced its shooting deaths with a focus on de-escalation of conflict and avoiding or minimising police use of force.

title.children: Family, experts speak out after Queensland Police shootings surpass rest of nation's total

image.altText: Pharmacist hands holding a slim box of pills

items.synopsis: A long-awaited trial of over-the-counter sales of emergency contraceptives is underway in Japan, but activists worry access to this essential medicine might only be temporary.

title.children: Japan finally trials over-the-counter sales of morning-after pill — but there's a catch

image.altText: a man and a woman smile at the camera standing in front of a triple j sign

items.synopsis: Owen Wright was at the top of his game when he suffered a massive wipe-out that resulted in bleeding on the brain. With help from his partner, singer-songwriter Kita Alexander, he made an incredible comeback.

title.children: How surfer Owen Wright won an Olympic medal after suffering a brain injury

image.altText: A woman with coifed hair wearing a string of pearls and a black t-shirt stands with barbie dolls.

items.synopsis: Ruth Handler was the ambitious career woman who created Barbie and changed America's toy industry. But a tax fraud scandal ultimately saw her forced out of the company she co-founded, Mattel.

title.children: The Barbie movie featured a tongue-in-cheek joke about the doll's creator. This is the story of Ruth Handler

image.altText: Fans in a crowd cheer on their team.

items.synopsis: From having their seats given away, to being made to feel unwelcome, people with disabilities have long felt on the outer at major events. So what has FIFA been doing to make this Women's World Cup more accessible?

title.children: Major events are rarely accessible to disabled people. Is the Women's World Cup any different?

image.altText: A smiling man in a suit and tie

items.synopsis: The head of ABC's investigations unit Jo Puccini says she did not check the source material that led to stories about allegations of a war crime because it was not her job and she trusted the journalist.

title.children: 'It's not my job': ABC investigations boss admits she didn't check stories alleging war crimes

image.altText: Blue and white Brisbane Watch House sign

items.synopsis: A lawyer labels the detention of children in a watch houses "a serious breach of human rights" after a judge ordered three children be moved urgently.

title.children: Queensland judge orders urgent transfer of three children to youth detention from watch houses

image.altText: A composite photo of Australian and Chinese flags combined with a grain photo overlaid

items.synopsis: China has dropped its 80 per cent tariffs on Australian barley, after a long-running and high-profile trade war between the two nations.

title.children: China ditches Australian barley tariffs after long-running trade war

image.altText: Three people stand by the side of the road holding 'save lee point' posters. They are happy.

items.synopsis: Work on the Lee Point project will pause until March after Larrakia traditional owners made an emergency application to federal Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek on the grounds of protecting Aboriginal cultural heritage.

title.children: Defence Housing Australia puts Darwin's Lee Point development on hold until 2024

image.altText: Close up of a young person's hands gripping a wire fence

items.synopsis: Police say they are unprepared and fearing the possibility of legal repercussions just days after the NT government changed the age of criminal responsibility.

title.children: NT Police union fears 'mistakes will be made' after new training for arresting children was 'rushed'

image.altText: A close up of Lauren Willgoose with a serious expression on her face

items.synopsis: A woman accused of killing a prominent South Australian neuropsychologist in a hit-and-run crash on Goodwood Road has given evidence in Adelaide's District Court, rejecting prosecution accusations that she knew she had hit a pedestrian.

title.children: CCTV shows fatal crash accused drinking five glasses of wine at nearby hotel, court told

image.altText: A house cordoned off with police tape.

items.synopsis: Judith Ann Venn had "reached the end of the road", when she fed her husband his "favourite" vegetable soup, which was laced with 50 pills of his prescription medication.

title.children: Woman, 69, jailed for killing abusive husband with spiked vegetable soup

image.altText: Red Incitec Pivot sign and logo at fertiliser plant at Port Adelaide.

items.synopsis: A state-owned Indonesian company is the frontrunner to buy Incitec Pivot but some farmers want it to stay Australian-owned.

title.children: Farmers concerned by foreign bid for Australia's biggest fertiliser manufacturer

image.altText: A row of wind turbines in a field

items.synopsis: The company behind the Willatook Wind Farm project says it looks unlikely to go ahead because state government environmental requirements make it unviable.

title.children: Victorian wind farm project facing turbulence following 'unworkable' environmental recommendations

image.altText: a woman holding a small child in the doorway of a burnt out home

items.synopsis: Winter temperatures have neared 40 degrees Celsius in parts of South America, which is up to 20C higher than normal for this time of year and the equivalent of Sydney hitting 35C in the first week of August.

title.children: Mid-winter temperatures in South America rival those of the baking northern hemisphere summer

image.altText: Elderly man standing in front of court sliding doors with hand behind his back wearing striped jumper

items.synopsis: Alan Charles Jones walks free from court in Albany despite being convicted of sexually abusing a boy 40 years ago.

title.children: Elderly child sex offender avoids jail over historical offences in country WA

image.altText: Anthony Albanese, wearing a brown akubra hat and blue shirt, sits with a woman and man clapping

items.synopsis: The federal government will help fund the development of a new Indigenous-led tertiary education institute in north-east Arnhem Land.

title.children: Federal government commits $6.4m for 'world-class' Garma Institute

image.altText: A team of people dressed in red and white walk and wave through a stadium, with a Canadian flag.

items.synopsis: Commonwealth Sport Canada says it understands Victoria's recent decision to walk away from hosting the 2026 event was a "significant factor" behind Alberta's announcement.

title.children: Axing of Victoria's Commonwealth Games 'significant factor' in Canadian province backing out of hosting bid

image.altText: Two men and a woman walk outside a court building

items.synopsis: An Adelaide court hears there were three grounds for Warren Tredrea's dismissal, which included reputational damage following "inaccurate" comments made on a local radio station about the COVID-19 vaccine.

title.children: Multiple grounds for Channel Nine sports presenter's dismissal, court hears

image.altText: A woman sits on a stage behind a desk with a mic

items.synopsis: Academic, political and business leaders have weighed in on the prevalence of "unacceptable" protest tactics, after four activists were outside the family home of Woodside's CEO.

title.children: Activists, leaders condemn Woodside protest tactics as premier reprimands ABC over coverage

image.altText: A court sketch depicts Donald Trump with his trademark coiffed blonde hair, blue suit and red tie, hands folded on a table

items.synopsis: Donald Trump's third indictment marks an extraordinary moment: a former president is fighting charges over his handling of the last election, while campaigning to win the next one.

title.children: Why Donald Trump’s third indictment could prove to be the most damaging

image.altText: Fish fillets on display at market, generic image.

items.synopsis: A study of fish sold in supermarkets and restaurants around Australia finds nearly 12 per cent of seafood is mislabelled, as researchers call for more stringent labelling laws.

title.children: DNA testing shows fishy labelling of popular seafoods rife around Australia

image.altText: A composite image of brothers Obaid and Shaheryer Khan, wearing suits outside court.

items.synopsis: Two brothers are facing the prospect of jail and deportation from Australia, over their involvement in a counterfeit stamp scam led by their older brother, a court hears.

title.children: It started with an Alibaba order. It could end with two brothers being deported

image.altText: Neil Gaughan at a Senate Committee.

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police is forced to correct the record and clarify that Opposition Leader Peter Dutton was not briefed on the identity of a man later jailed for bribing Nauru government officials.

title.children: AFP admits Peter Dutton was not specifically briefed on concerns over Nauru businessman

image.altText: A man in police uniform sits at a desk with a small microphone and nameplate in front of him.

items.synopsis: Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw rubbishes suggestions he should have declared a conflict of interest over his friendship with a senior PwC partner with whom he discussed a contract for the consulting firm.

title.children: 'No apologies': AFP commissioner rubbishes claims he should have declared friendship with PwC partner

image.altText: Two people holding big fish.

items.synopsis: For a long time a lot of the region's wild-caught barra was sent to southern states for processing, but Darwin's first major fish processing facility aims to cut the distance fresh seafood travels before hitting local plates.

title.children: Darwin barramundi facility aims to cut waste, reduce food miles

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie looks down as a microphone is held to his face

items.synopsis: NSW Police seized Mahmoud Abbas laptop and other electronic devices after he was shot outside his home in Greenacre on July 26.

title.children: Sydney lawyer shot in 'targeted' attack challenges police access to seized laptop

image.altText: A woman dressed up and smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: The family of Gulgong schoolgirl Michelle Bright who was murdered while walking home from a party 24 years ago, say her killer took away her dreams and tore their family apart.

title.children: 'Instead of celebrating birthdays, we take flowers to the cemetery': Slain teen's family confront 'monster' killer
